item.title: Lonliness of the Long Distance Landline
item.description:
Recent data shows people are rapidly ditching landlines. If Alexander Graham Bell were alive today, he’d have trouble reaching anyone on his original invention. Instead, he’d have much better luck using a cell phone, just like everyone else. It’s not surprising that most people own a cell phone, or even multiple old ones. People want to be constantly connected, even when they perhaps shouldn’t be. Observe drivers at a stoplight, and you’ll likely spot several talking on their phones...

item.title: Regulation of Audiovisual Media Services and the "Exception for Newspapers
item.description:
Lorna Woods, Professor of Internet Law, University of Essex Case C-347/14 New Media Online GmbH v. Bundeskommunikationssenat, 21 October 2015 Traditionally, broadcasting and newspapers have been regulated differently. Newspapers have enjoyed more lenient, often self-regulatory, oversight. EU law harmonized television broadcasting through the Television without Frontiers Directive. Newspapers, if subject to EU law, fell under general free movement and competition rules. As technology evolved and online information services emerged, the Television without Frontiers Directive underwent revisions, becoming the Audiovisual Media Services Directive...

item.title: Media Flos to Mobile TV
item.description:
Television is everywhere. While it started with over-the-air broadcasts, it quickly spread to cable, satellite, and the internet through platforms like YouTube and IPTV. Now, mobile devices like cell phones are the new frontier for watching TV on the go. Early mobile video relied on downloadable clips using cellular broadband networks like EV-DO. However, these networks struggle with bandwidth limitations, making it difficult to deliver high-quality real-time video without overloading the system...
